what: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: R package fastpos provides fast algorithm calculate required sample size Pearson correlation stabilize within sequential framework (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013, 2018). Basically, one wants find sample size one can sure 1-α percent many studies fall specified corridor stability around assumed population correlation stay inside corridor participants added study. instance, find many participants per study required , 100k studies, 90% fall region .4 .6 (Pearson correlation) leave region participants added (assumption population correlation .5). sample size also referred critical point stability specific parameters. approach related AO-method sample size planning (e.g. Algina & Olejnik, 2003) can seen alternative power analysis. Unlike AO, concept stability incorporates idea sequentially adding participants study. Although approach young, already attracted lot interest psychological research community, evident 800 citations original publication (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013). Still, date, exists easy way use stability approach individual sample size planning analytical solution problem simulation approach computationally expensive . presented package overcomes limitation speeding calculation correlations achieving . typical parameters, theoretical speedup least around factor 250. empirical benchmark typical scenario even shows speedup 400, paving way wider usage stability approach.

title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: can install released version fastpos CRAN : can install development version GitHub devtools:

title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: Since found page, assume either want (1) calculate critical point stability study (2) explore method general. case, read find looking . Let us first load package set seed reproducibility: cases just need function find_critical_pos give critical point stability specific parameters. Let us reproduce Schönbrodt Perugini’s quite famous oft-cited table critical points stability precision 0.1. reduce number studies 10k use multicore support (works GNU/Linux) runs fairly quickly. results close Schönbrodt Perugini’s table (see https://github.com/nicebread/corEvol). Note warning shown, simulations corridor stability reached. long number low, affect estimates much. want get accurate estimates, increase maximum sample size. want dig deeper, can look functions find_critical_pos builds upon. simulate_pos workhorse package. calls C++ function calculate correlations sequentially pretty quickly (know already, right?). rawish approach create population create_pop pass simulate_pos:  Note warning message appears corridor reached, instead NA value returned. Pay careful attention work function, adjust maximum sample size needed. create_pop creates population matrix using method described (https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/15011/generate--random-variable---defined-correlation---existing-variables/15040#15040). much simpler way Schönbrodt Perugini’s approach, results seem differ. interested population parameters (e.g. skewness) affect point stability, instead refer population generating functions Schönbrodt Perugini’s work.
code: library(fastpos) set.seed(19950521) n_cores <- parallel::detectCores() - 1 find_critical_pos(rho = seq(.1, .7, .1), sample_size_max = 1e3,                   n_studies = 10e3, n_cores = n_cores) #> Warning in find_critical_pos(rho = seq(0.1, 0.7, 0.1), sample_size_max = 1000, : 33 simulation[s] did not reach the corridor of #>             stability. #> Increase sample_size_max and rerun the simulation. #>   rho_pop pos.80% pos.90% pos.95% sample_size_min sample_size_max lower_limit #> 1     0.1     254   363.0  477.00              20            1000         0.0 #> 2     0.2     241   341.0  452.05              20            1000         0.1 #> 3     0.3     214   307.1  406.00              20            1000         0.2 #> 4     0.4     180   262.0  347.00              20            1000         0.3 #> 5     0.5     144   209.0  270.00              20            1000         0.4 #> 6     0.6     105   154.0  203.00              20            1000         0.5 #> 7     0.7      65    95.1  126.00              20            1000         0.6 #>   upper_limit n_studies n_not_breached precision_absolute precision_relative #> 1         0.2     10000             11                0.1                 NA #> 2         0.3     10000             13                0.1                 NA #> 3         0.4     10000              7                0.1                 NA #> 4         0.5     10000              2                0.1                 NA #> 5         0.6     10000              0                0.1                 NA #> 6         0.7     10000              0                0.1                 NA #> 7         0.8     10000              0                0.1                 NA pop <- create_pop(0.5, 1e6) pos <- simulate_pos(x_pop = pop[,1],                     y_pop = pop[,2],                     n_studies = 1e4,                     sample_size_min = 20,                     sample_size_max = 1e3,                     replace = T,                     lower_limit = 0.4,                     upper_limit = 0.6,                     progress = FALSE) hist(pos, xlim = c(0, 1e3), xlab = c("Point of stability"),      main = "Histogram of points of stability for rho = .5+-.1") quantile(pos, c(.8, .9, .95), na.rm = T) #>   80%   90%   95%  #> 142.0 207.0 274.1

title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: Since version 0.4.0 fastpos supports multiple cores. first attempts implement quite unsuccessful several reasons: (1) Higher-level parallelism R makes difficult show progress C++, important time-demanding calculations happen (2) parallelizing solutions work operating systems (e.g. mcpbapply) (3) overhead can quite large, especially small number simulation runs. thought best solution directly parallelize C++. tried RcppThread, end even slower singlethreading. assume experienced C++ programmer make work parallelizing C++ feels bit like torture. intermediate solution quite simple pragmatic: use futures. divided number studies available cores , started  simulations via futures multisession plan. Meanwhile main R process also started simulation, wich showed progress bar C++. simulations ended approximately time, progress bar finished futures resolved. points stability combined rest program worked singlethreaded version. Unfortunately solution bring substantial speed benefits. Since version 0.5.0 switched parallel package pbapply. means multicore support Windows implementation simple shows substantial speed benefits. Even small simulations benefits clearly visible: test done server 32 cores, 31 cores used.
code: onecore <- function() {   find_critical_pos(0.5) } multicore <- function() {   find_critical_pos(0.5, n_cores = n_cores) } microbenchmark::microbenchmark(onecore(), multicore(), times = 10) #> Unit: seconds #>         expr       min        lq      mean    median        uq      max neval #>    onecore() 26.442229 26.520269 27.271985 27.355036 27.806570 28.42687    10 #>  multicore()  2.256679  2.384302  2.550777  2.486456  2.522117  3.05895    10

title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: introduction boldly claimed fastpos much faster original implementation Schönbrodt Perugini (corEvol). theoretical argument goes follows: corEvol calculates every correlation scratch. take sum formula correlation coefficient r_{xy} = \frac{n\sum x_i y_i - \sum x_i \sum y_i} {\sqrt{n\sum x_i^2-(\sum x_i)^2} \sqrt{n\sum y_i^2-(\sum y_i)^2}} can see several sums calculated, consisting adding  (sample size) terms. done every sample size minimum maximum one. Thus, total number added terms one sum : \sum _{n_\mathrm{min}}^{n_\mathrm{max}}n = \sum_{n=1}^{n_\mathrm{max}}n - \sum_{n=1}^{n_\mathrm{min}-1}n = n_\mathrm{max}(n_\mathrm{max}+1)/2 -(n_\mathrm{min}-1)(n_\mathrm{min}-1+1)/2 hand, fastpos calculates correlation maximum sample size first. requires add  numbers one sum. subtracts one value sum find correlation sample size , happens repeatedly minimum sample size reached. Overall total number terms one sum amounts : n_\mathrm{max}+n_\mathrm{max}-n_\mathrm{min} ratio two approaches : \frac{n_\mathrm{max}(n_\mathrm{max}+1)/2 -(n_\mathrm{min}-1)n_\mathrm{min}/2}{2n_\mathrm{max}-n_\mathrm{min}} typically used  1000  20, can expect speedup 250. approximation several reasons. First, one can stop process corridor reached, done fastpos corEvol. Second, main function fastpos written C++ (via Rcpp), much faster R. time, algorithms involve many steps just calculating correlations. instance, setting population specific  takes time since ususally consists million value pairs. interface functions setup simulations also play important role. Obviously, lower time limit beat. Thus, necessary study speed benefit empirically. theoretical difference big suffice give rough benchmark following parameters chosen: rho = .1, sample_size_max = 1000, sample_size_min = 20, n_studies = 10000. Note corEvol written script simulation study thus simply called via function. Furthermore, simulation run takes lot time thus practical run many times. want experiment benchmark, forked original corEvol repository made benchmark branch (note work GNU/Linux, since using git bash): corEvol, two files “sourced” benchmark. first file generates simulations second calculating critical point stability. turned messages produced source files. chosen parameters, fastpos 131 times faster corEvol, two main reasons: (1) fastpos built around C++ function via Rcpp (2) function calculate every calculation scratch, calculates difference correlation sample size   via sum formula Pearson correlation (see ). factors might play role, account large difference found. instance, setting population takes quite long corEvol (20s), compared ~6 min required overall, small fraction. parts corEvol code fated slow, , speedup factor 131 achieved improving parts. presented benchmark definitely comprehensive, demonstrates fastpos can used significant waiting time typical scenario, corEvol case.
code: git -C corEvol pull || git clone --single-branch --branch benchmark \   https://github.com/johannes-titz/corEvol library(microbenchmark) setwd("corEvol") corevol <- function() {   source("01-simdata.R")   source("02-analyse.R") } fastpos <- function() {   find_critical_pos(rho = .1, sample_size_max = 1e3, n_studies = 10e3) } bm <- microbenchmark(corevol = corevol(), fastpos = fastpos(), times = 10,                      unit = "s") #>  #> Attache Paket: 'dplyr' #> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #> Lade nötiges Paket: foreach #> Lade nötiges Paket: iterators #> Lade nötiges Paket: parallel bm #> Unit: seconds #>     expr        min         lq       mean     median         uq        max #>  corevol 361.441778 362.906572 363.250371 363.234010 363.817974 364.638600 #>  fastpos   2.711718   2.723252   2.776013   2.755461   2.832309   2.880485 #>  neval #>     10 #>     10

what: What does fastpos do if the corridor of stability is not reached for a simulation study?
title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: case fastpos return NA value point stability. calculating quantiles, fastpos use maximum sample size, reasonable estimate ignoring specific simulation study altogether.

what: Why does fastpos produce different estimates to corEvol?
title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: parameters used, differences rather small. general, differences avoided entirely due random nature whole process. Even algorithm used, estimates vary slightly run run. important aspect studies treated point stability reached: corEvol ignores , fastpos assumes corridor reached maximum sample size. Thus, parameters , fastpos tend produce larger estimates, accurate (conservative). note corridor stability reached, increase maximum sample size. Previously, feasible due computational demands, fastpos usually can done.

title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation

title: Finds the Critical Sequential Point of Stability for a Pearson Correlation
text: Comments feedback kind welcome! thoroughly consider every suggestion improve code, documentation, presented examples. Even minor things, suggestions better wording improving grammar part package, welcome. want make pull request, please check can still build package without errors, warnings, notes. Overall, simply stick R packages book: https://r-pkgs.org/

title: Summary
text: R package fastpos provides fast algorithm calculate required sample size Pearson correlation stabilize within sequential framework [@schonbrodt2013;@schonbrodt2018]. Basically, one wants find sample size one can sure 1 − α percent many studies fall specified corridor stability around assumed population correlation stay inside corridor participants added study. instance, find many participants per study required , 100k studies, 90% fall region .4 .6 (Pearson correlation) leave region participants added (assumption population correlation .5). sample size also referred critical point stability specific parameters. approach related accuracy parameter estimation [AIPE, e.g. @maxwell2008] can seen alternative power analysis. Unlike AIPE, concept stability incorporates idea sequentially adding participants study. Although approach young, already attracted lot interest psychological research community, evident 600 citations original publication [@schonbrodt2013]. date exists easy way use sequential stability individual sample size planning analytical solution problem simulation approach computationally expensive. package fastpos overcomes limitation speeding calculation correlations. typical parameters, theoretical speedup least around 250. empirical benchmark typical scenario even shows speedup 500, paving way wider usage stability approach.

what: Find the critical point of stability — find_critical_pos
title: Find the critical point of stability — find_critical_pos
text: Run simulations one several population correlations return critical points stability (POS). critical point stability sample size certain percentage studies fall priori specified interval stay interval sample size increased .

title: Find the critical point of stability — find_critical_pos
code: find_critical_pos(   rho,   precision_absolute = 0.1,   confidence_levels = c(0.8, 0.9, 0.95),   sample_size_min = 20,   sample_size_max = 1000,   replace = TRUE,   n_studies = 1e+05,   pop_size = 1e+06,   n_cores = 1,   precision_relative = NA,   lower_limit = NA,   upper_limit = NA,   progress = show_progress(),   precision = lifecycle::deprecated(),   precision_rel = lifecycle::deprecated(),   rhos = lifecycle::deprecated() )

title: Find the critical point of stability — find_critical_pos
text: rho Vector population correlations (can also single correlation). precision_absolute Precision around correlation acceptable (defaults 0.1). precision determine corridor stability just rho+-precision. Can single value vector (different values different rhos). confidence_levels Confidence levels point stability. corresponds quantile distribution found critical sample sizes (defaults c(.8, .9, .95)). single value can also used. Note value fixed rhos! specify different levels different rhos. sample_size_min Minimum sample size study (defaults 20). vector can used (different values different rhos). sample_size_max Maximum sample size study (defaults 1e3). vector can used (different values different rhos). get warning corridor stability reached, increase value. note increase time simulation. replace Whether drawing samples replacement . Default TRUE, usually changed. parameter mainly interest researchers studying method detail. vector can used (different values different rhos). n_studies Number studies run rho (defaults 10e3). vector can used (different values different rhos). pop_size Population size (defaults 1e6). size population value pairs correlations drawn. value usually decreased can lead less accurate results. n_cores Number cores use simulation. Defaults 1. precision_relative Relative precision around correlation (rho+-rho*precision), set, overwrite precision_absolute. vector can used (different values different rhos). lower_limit Lower limit corridor, overrides precision parameters. vector can used (different values different rhos). used, upper_limit must also set. upper_limit Upper limit corridor, overrides precision parameters. vector can used (different values different rhos). used, lower_limit must also set. progress progress bar displayed? Logical, default show progress run interactive mode. precision , use precision_absolute instead precision_rel , use precision_relative instead rhos , use rho instead

title: Find the critical point of stability — find_critical_pos
text: data frame containing information, well critical points stability. points stability follow directly first column (rho) named pos.confidence-level, e.g. pos.80, pos.90, pos.95 default confidence levels.

title: Find the critical point of stability — find_critical_pos
code: find_critical_pos(rho = 0.5, n_studies = 1e3) #>   rho_pop pos.80% pos.90% pos.95% sample_size_min sample_size_max lower_limit #> 1     0.5     143   204.1   268.1              20            1000         0.4 #>   upper_limit n_studies n_not_breached precision_absolute precision_relative #> 1         0.6      1000              0                0.1                 NA find_critical_pos(rho = c(0.4, 0.5), n_studies = 1e3) #>   rho_pop pos.80% pos.90% pos.95% sample_size_min sample_size_max lower_limit #> 1     0.4   169.2   233.2   324.0              20            1000         0.3 #> 2     0.5   149.0   214.2   293.1              20            1000         0.4 #>   upper_limit n_studies n_not_breached precision_absolute precision_relative #> 1         0.5      1000              0                0.1                 NA #> 2         0.6      1000              0                0.1                 NA

title: Simulate several points of stability — simulate_pos
code: simulate_pos(   x_pop,   y_pop,   n_studies,   sample_size_min,   sample_size_max,   replace,   lower_limit,   upper_limit,   progress )

title: Simulate several points of stability — simulate_pos
text: x_pop First vector population. y_pop Second vector population. n_studies many studies conduct. sample_size_min Minimum sample size start corridor stability. sample_size_max many participants draw maximum. replace Whether drawing samples replacement . lower_limit Lower limit corridor stability. upper_limit Upper limit corridor stability. progress progress bar displayed? Boolean, default FALSE.

title: Simulate several points of stability — simulate_pos
text: Vector sample sizes corridor stability reached.

title: Simulate several points of stability — simulate_pos
text: just want calculate quantile distribution, use main function package find_critical_pos()).

title: Simulate several points of stability — simulate_pos
code: # set up a population pop <- fastpos::create_pop(rho = 0.5, size = 1e6) # create a distribution of points of stability pos <- simulate_pos(x_pop = pop[,1], y_pop = pop[,2], n_studies = 100,                     sample_size_min = 20, sample_size_max = 1e3,                     replace = TRUE, lower_limit = 0.4, upper_limit = 0.6,                     progress = TRUE) # calculate quantiles or any other parameter of the distribution quantile(pos, c(.8, .9, .95), na.rm = TRUE) #>   80%   90%   95%  #> 167.4 206.5 330.1

title: fastpos 0.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-09-29 tests now show information fail, also tolerance individual deviation higher avoid false alarms progress bars shown R run interactively (required per manual writing R extensions)

title: fastpos 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-08-10 multiple cores now supported via future package, use parameter n_cores, gains visible n_studies high (overhead) tests multiple cores included replace parameter added externally visible functions, tests replace = false minor improvements layout/documentation test added old pop_create function test coverage now somewhat higher since untestable proportion code reduced

title: fastpos 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-02-17 Parameter number studies now always n_studies. lower level functions used number_of_studies. create_pop now creates bivariate normal distribution exact rho, slower previously, probably worth . Problems C++ progressbar (RcppProgress) fixed. code also cleaner now. Make C++ Rstudio interruption similar: depending timing, either Rstudio interrupts stops everything C++ returns value. latter case, R now also stops quietly. Since interrupts properly tested, code coverage 90%.

title: fastpos 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-01-10 corridor stability reached, NA returned internal function simulate_pos build upon. n_not_breached simply number NA values. maximum sample size still used calculation quantiles corridor reached, better ignoring specific study altogether (.e. treating NA value). simulate_pos now returns IntegerVector (instead NumericVector) better handle NA values. simple test relative precision added. Another test added unloads package. Code coverage now 100%. vignette readme improved substantially. Word choice grammar checked editor. section speed fastpos comparison corEvol added including theoretical argument empirical test.

title: fastpos 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-12-13 First release
